node.title: Jennifer visited a museum and saw her own heart on display
node.alt: A woman in her 20s looks at her own heart at a museum exhibition
node.description: The history of medical transplants stretches back millennia and includes some bizarre and gruesome milestones.
node.content:
["When Jennifer Sutton visited a London museum in 2007, she came face-to-face with an unlikely object on display: her own heart.", "Ms Sutton had undergone a heart transplant just a few months prior and agreed to lend her old organ to the Wellcome Collection medical museum for a new exhibition.", "The moment of Ms Sutton looking at her heart-turned-museum-piece was captured in a series of photos, which featured in media outlets across the UK and the world.", "\"It immediately raised quite fundamental questions. What does it mean to have a body? What does it mean to be an individual? What does it mean to have an identity? All of these things seemed to be raised when I looked at those images.\"", "Dr Craddock was so fascinated by the photos that he decided to start researching the history of transplant surgery, which culminated in his recent book, the aptly-titled Spare Parts.", "
Fit for Indian kings
", "Dr Craddock, who is an honorary senior research associate at UCL's division of surgery and a visiting lecturer at Imperial College London, says the history of transplant surgery stretches back millennia.", "He points to an Indian medical text called the Sushruta Samhita from the 6th century BCE as having the earliest reference to a rudimentary transplant operation.", "In addition to describing 1,120 illnesses and 700 medicinal plants, the text details several methods of skin grafts \u2014 or transplanting a piece of skin from one part of a person's body to another.", "It stipulates that if a surgeon knew these procedures, they were good enough to treat a king.", "\"And that was a catalogue of procedures that was already considered traditional. So that's the first reference, but [the procedures] are probably much older than that,\" Dr Craddock says.", "
Lost noses in Renaissance Italy
", "The next in-depth references to skin grafts come thousands of years later, in 16th century Italy.", "\"It was used to treat lost noses,\" Dr Craddock says.", "\"If you went to war, you could get a sabre cut and have your nose lopped off. Same thing with a duel \u2026 And also syphilis, it was a particularly horrible disease at that time, which would rot the nose off,\" he says", "The skin grafting procedure would involve taking the skin of a patient's arm and attaching it to their face, or as Dr Craddock puts it, \"you'd end up walking around with your bicep area grafted to your own nose.\"", "", "
A late 1500s Italian\u00a0engraving shows how to transplant\u00a0skin from the upper arm to restore the nose.(Getty Images:\u00a0De Agostini Picture Library)
", "The technique was a closely-held secret among certain Italian families, but in the 1540s, surgeon Leonardo Fioravanti snuck in during one operation, watched the process and wrote it all down.", "The renegade Italian was able to put it into practice\u00a0some time later. In his writings, he says he was walking with a friend, when an Ottoman soldier picked a fight and cut his friend's nose off.", "\"Fioravanti basically writes that, 'well, I picked up the nose and I pissed on it, to wash away all of the sand',\" Dr Craddock says.", "\"Then he took this urine-soaked nose, stuck it back on his friend's face, and applied a bandage. When he removed the bandage, it was 'magically' attached \u2026 The graft took.\"", "Regardless of whether the story is entirely true or not, the technique (minus the urine) was in use until World War II.", "\"There are pictures of Second World War soldiers with their forearms grafted to their noses,\" Dr Craddock says.", "
Animal\u00a0blood and children's teeth
", "In the 17th century, European doctors (or in most cases, so-called doctors) started to experiment with blood transfusions.", "But rather than human blood, they injected their patients with animal blood.", "\"In France, you had a doctor called Jean-Baptiste Denys, and he used lamb's blood to 'cure' madness in people, because lambs are innocent and sweet, there's the Lamb of God, and all that sort of stuff,\" Dr Craddock says.", "\"They thought that transfusing the animal blood would somehow transfuse a bit of their personality, or a bit of their soul, and it could, in that way, be used to treat some conditions.\"", "Cat's blood was thought to cure epilepsy (which was then called \"falling sickness\"), donkey's blood could supposedly cure fever and an ox's blood was meant to cure dysentery.", "", "
European 'doctors' in the 1600s thought animal blood could be used to cure all sorts of illnesses.(Getty Images: Ullstein Bild Dtl)
", "One etching from late 1600s Europe shows a nervous-looking patient receiving a blood transfusion from a dog that's tied up to the ceiling.", "It's unclear if the patient survived, or, like many other recipients of animal blood, died.", "This was pseudoscience but it paved the way for far more effective and life-saving human-to-human blood transfusions centuries later.", "And as the years and animal blood transfusions ticked by, another type of transplant developed in Europe: teeth.", "", "
An engraving ridicules the\u00a018th century fashion of tooth transplantation from living donors.(Getty Images: Science & Society Picture Library)
", "Tooth transplants became particularly popular in Georgian England among those who could afford it.", "Dentists sourced teeth \u2014 typically live teeth from poorer children \u2014 and would then transplant them into the mouths of older, richer patients.", "\"[It was] a horrible practice,\" Dr Craddock says.", "
The 'heroic, maverick figures'
", "It wasn't until the 20th century that medical transplants became truly life-saving.", "The early 1900s brought the discovery of blood types and the first reliable methods of sewing blood vessels together, which meant organs could be connected into a body.", "\"Those two procedures \u2014 the blood typing and operations on blood vessels \u2014 they're traditionally seen as the start of transplant surgery,\" Dr Craddock says.", "After these developments, the race was on.", "", "
The South African medical team conducting the first successful heart transplant in\u00a01967.(Getty Images:\u00a0Bettmann)
", "In 1954, American Joseph Murray performed the first successful kidney transplant.", "Then in 1967, South African Christiaan Barnard performed the first heart transplant.", "\"These heroic, maverick figures were very popular after World War II. They telegraphed a kind of competence and optimism,\" Dr Craddock says.", "Today, organ transplants are routine operations around the world.", "According to figures from the Australian government, 1,270 Australian lives were saved in 2020 through an organ transplant.", "However, there are around 1,800 Australians currently waitlisted for a transplant, prompting the government to regularly call on all Australians to register to be an organ donor.", "
The future
", "Dr Craddock says the next few years will bring more big leaps forward in medical transplant technology.", "He points to stem cell science and bioengineering as just some of the many new frontiers.", "\"We're moving towards transplanting stem cells onto some kind of scaffold, so populating a scaffold with our own cells and transplanting that or implanting that [into the body],\" he says.", "\"Technically, it's possible to print body parts. But there aren't any 3D printers that can manage tiny capillaries and little vessels yet.\"", "And developments like this will mean even more lives will be saved by the medical miracle of transplant surgery in the years ahead."]
